Award.AwardTitle: Photochromic Ruthenium Sulfoxide Complexes: Ultrafast Spectroscopy and Photomechanical Effects
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Chemistry Division supports Professor Jeffrey Rack at Ohio University for studies into the development of photochromic ruthenium sulfoxide complexes. Photochromism in these compounds arises from conversion between isomers in which the sulfoxide is bonded to the ruthenium through sulfur and ones in which the sulfoxide is attached to the ruthenium through oxygen. New examples of these compounds will be synthesized to test the role of sterically-hindered ligands on the excited state rate constant for the isomerization. Femtosecond transient absorption spectroscopy will be employed to determine the rate constants along with their wavelength, solvent and temperature dependence. Identification of intermediates on the femtosecond and picosecond timescale is an important goal. Complexes that feature two-color reversible photochromism will be incorporated into polymers that will feature photomechanical effects. Such effects are exceptionally rare and a new procedure for measuring strain in polymers featuring photomechanical effects will be developed.

Students associated with this project will be trained in the areas of inorganic, physical, analytical and organic chemistry. The multi-disciplinary nature of the project will demand that the student be aware of literature contributions in disparate research areas. Involvement of underrepresented groups is also a genuine goal of this project. Ohio University is located in Athens, OH a rural, chronically economically depressed area in Appalachia. Ohio University is deeply committed to the education and training of a student population with a significantly higher than national prevalence of low-income, first generation college students. Indeed, of those undergraduate students performing research in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, 40% are from one of the 29 counties in Appalachia. The students associated with this project will be involved in a number of divisional, departmental, College, University and Community outreach and interactive programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The past granting period resulted in great growth of a new class of photochromic compounds. Photochromic compounds are those that change color when exposed to light. The light may be coherent, in the form of a laser, or non-coherent, in the form of the sun, or typical room lighting. In general, these compounds have application in advanced computing (holography), photonics (advanced optical devices) and optical limiting devices. A common commerical product involving a photochromic material is Transition lenses. 

The growth in our class of photochromic compounds came not only from the type of available compounds, but also through control of the color of these compounds. We designed new complexes that featured a colorless (UV) to colored (visible) transformation. We also determined the efficiency and the amount of time required for this transformation employing femtosecond pump probe spectroscopy. In general, the new individual compounds undergo their color change rapidly, within hundreds of picoseconds (10-12 s), and efficiently, with quantum yields ranging from 30 - 70% (the largest quantum yield is 100%).

The nature of the color change in these materials is a light triggered isomerization, or atom rearrangement. For the new group of compounds discussed above, they feature two isomerizing groups. In a surprising set of experiments, we found that the number and types of atoms that link the isomerizing groups is important in determining the rate of the color change and the efficiency of the color change. In fact, we discovered that a three atom linker is better than a two atom linker (See Primary Image). These results are important because they prompt us to think more critically and creatively about how photonic energy (light) is converted to potential energy in order to facilitate and prompt this excited state reaction. More specifically, following light excitation of a molecule, certain of the energy is converted into vibrational energy. For the complexes studied here, these vibrations are not associated with the electronic transition, yet they have a demonstrable influence on the product of the reaction. The standard models suggest that the vibrations associated with an electronic transition are those that receive energy from the electronic excitation. Thus, these results require us to consider how these vibrations are promoted, and to think more deeply about how this reaction occurs. 

The students on this project received a rigorous education in inorganic and organic synthesis, as well as steady-state and laser spectrscopy. Primarily these students came from chronically and economically depressed Appalachian Ohio. This group included undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral researchers as well as a middle school student. This group was roughly divided equally between men and women. Funds in support of this project were utilized to send these students to regional, national and international conferences. 


Last Modified: 03/30/2016
Modified by: Jeffrey J Rack
